Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2010 07:45PM grayeyes wrote: DucorpsToo, Lisa1962, and rajkumari, Thank you for your replies.  It's good to meet all of you, and I'm glad I found this forum, too.  Your replies have been very helpful.  I received a call from an imaging center today.  Apparently, there was some confusion between doctors over what I should do next.  Bottom line:  I ended up with an earlier appointment for an ultrasound-guided biopsy next week and then the appointment with the surgeon the following week.  Hopefully, the biopsy will give good news, but I think I'm ready if it isn't. You all are so brave.  I am nervous about the biopsy, but it's good to know I can come to this forum for support through it all.  Thank you.
Posts.Title: New here, shocked and worried. grayeyes squidwitch42

Posts.Content: grayeyes wrote: Hi.  I'm 46 years old, married, and the mother of three.  The youngest is only nine. My father and his family all had cancer.  Just seven days ago, I noticed a breast lump.  It felt large, but I'd never noticed it before.  Within two days, I was at the gynecologist's office, and she ordered a mammogram. Earlier today, I had the mammo plus an ultrasound.  They had to keep taking the mammo over and over again because the lump was so far back.  The doctor there said it looks malignant because it's a "solid lesion" and it's spiculated (spiked?), meaning it's affecting the tissue around it.  It's 1.5 cm.  He said the lymph nodes don't look enlarged on the ultrasound.  But, he seemed very grim; he's sure it's cancer.  I ran home to hug my kids, and my husband came home early to hug me. I have an appointment for a biopsy with a breast surgeon in two weeks.  Now I'm hoping that doctor was wrong and this isn't cancer.  I'm wondering if he's rushing to a conclusion based on my family history.  I once had a vaginal tumor removed that turned out to be benign.  Has anyone here had a spiculated lesion that turned out to be benign?  Thank you, and thoughts and prayers for all of you. 2011: Left MX w/TE (Ki67: 60%) AC x 4, Taxol x 12, Radiation, Tamoxifen, BRCA2+ Dec. 2012: Right prophylactic MX w/TE, ooph; June 2013: Final exchange; Nov. 2013: Fat grafting; 2014: Arimidex; 2015: Femara REST IN PEACE, MELANIE Dx 11/23/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 2/22 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: New here, shocked and worried. grayeyes squidwitch42

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2010 07:11AM grayeyes wrote: Deanna, debbie6122, 3jaysmom, Thank you all for your replies.  The doctor is probably correct.  This just doesn't feel like anything I've felt before, which is why I ran to the doctor.  I'm just being hopeful. Thoughts and prayers for all of you this holiday.
Posts.Title: New here, shocked and worried. grayeyes squidwitch42

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2010 08:31PM grayeyes wrote: Apollo11, Thanks for your advice.  I hope and pray your surgeon finds that the lesion is benign.  It's nightmarish to have to endure all those tests and all the waiting and not knowing.   {{HUGS}}
Posts.Title: New here, shocked and worried. grayeyes squidwitch42
If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2012 07:58AM grayeyes wrote: FLtricia - At the treatment center where I received chemo, there were mostly senior citizens being treated, and I happen to know that one was in her 90's.  Most of them seemed to be doing well with the treatment; some were very spry, while there were others in wheelchairs, for example.  Those of us who were younger seemed to be the ones having all the complications.  I am sorry about what happened to your father; my father also passed away shortly after his one and only chemo treatment (long story).  I don't know what the best option for your mother is, but sometimes it seems the outcome might have less to do with age and more to do with other factors, perhaps, like overall health. I pray that it is not cancer, after all, and if it is, that the doctors can help her in the way that she decides is best for her. {{Hugs}}

Posts.Title: APBI, Cyberknife, Intravenous Vit C? grayeyes grayeyes
If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: grayeyes wrote: I posted here last week under "New, shocked and worried".  Quick review:  I just turned 46, married, three children.  The youngest is 9.  Following a mammogram and ultrasound, the doctor at the radiology center told me I have a 1.5 cm solid lesion that is spiculated.  He is sure it is cancer.  But, the biopsy won't be done until this Thursday.  I'm under a tremendous amount of stress for other reasons, and now this has upped the level of stress, as I'm worrying, not knowing if I have cancer spread throughout my body.  He said the lymph nodes on the mammo don't look swollen, but I've been reading that a 1.5 cm tumor could have metasticized.  Plus, I've been feeling fatigued for awhile now, which I thought was due to not getting enough sleep and not exercising.  Now I'm wondering...  I'm also worried about every little pain. Also, I read some tumors can grow within a couple of weeks.  I wish I could be in a hospital right now having everything done all at once.  My father felt the same way when he had cancer:  Being an outpatient was the worst part of it all, because all you do is wait and worry. My husband has been more than supportive.  But, aside from the internet, there's no one else around whom I can talk to.  I told my brother, and we agreed I should wait for the biopsy before telling my mother because she won't be able to handle it, after losing my father three years ago.  I know many people, but I have no close friends with whom to confide.  And we definitely don't want to tell our children until we have all the information ourselves, although they sense that something is wrong. Anyway, I've been researching, and I read about APBI.  I was excited about the possibility that, if the tumor is small enough, and if the cancer hasn't spread, they might be able to target the radiation to one area in 1 - 5 days. Then, last night, I found out there is a technology called Cyberknife that destroys tumors using pinpoint radiation.  I found articles that said it could be used for breast tumors.  I was so hopeful.  But, today, I called the Cyberknife center near me and was told they never use it on breast tumors.  I looked up more info and found that doctors prefer to radiate the entire breast.  But, doesn't APBI pinpoint radition, too? If anyone here has any experience with APBI or Cyberknife, I'd appreciate knowing more. Also, when my father was ill, and I was desperately looking for a way to save his life, I read about people using Intravenous Vitamin C.  There are doctors around here who will give it to cancer patients.  But, there are no studies to back it up.  Has anyone here ever used IV Vit C as either a treatment, a supplement, or both? These two weeks have been awful.  I know we're all in the same situation.  I'm trying to hold it all together and be strong, but I'm having a hard time.  I'm so grateful for this forum.  Thank you again.  2011: Left MX w/TE (Ki67: 60%) AC x 4, Taxol x 12, Radiation, Tamoxifen, BRCA2+ Dec. 2012: Right prophylactic MX w/TE, ooph; June 2013: Final exchange; Nov. 2013: Fat grafting; 2014: Arimidex; 2015: Femara REST IN PEACE, MELANIE Dx 11/23/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 2/22 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: APBI, Cyberknife, Intravenous Vit C? grayeyes grayeyes

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 07:37PM grayeyes wrote: I forgot to answer the question:  It will be an ultrasound-guided biopsy.  I was told they'll insert a tube and then a wire to extract a tissue sample.
Posts.Title: APBI, Cyberknife, Intravenous Vit C? grayeyes grayeyes

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 07:34PM grayeyes wrote: Redsox and JanetinVirginia, Thanks for the info about APBI.  Now I understand.  I appreciate all of the advice, too. You're both right, of course.  I need to calm down.  ;-)  I've been so spoiled by being blessed with good health all my life; I've never had any medical issues.  So many people have to deal with medical issues their entire lives.  I've been so fortunate when it comes to good health.  It's just that the timing couldn't be worse:  Recently, a younger relative was diagnosed with a different form of cancer, and I've been upset for her.  Now, if the doctor is right, it might be me who's sick, too.  Also, there are other things happening at the same time. I admire the strength I see here.  I hope my post didn't frighten any of the other newbies.  I was just flipping out.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 12:50AM grayeyes wrote: Slinky, Good luck today!  I think those worries are normal.  I was driving myself insane with the worrying, and I'm still having difficulty staying positive and focused.  At least having the surgery was a relief!  I hope it's as much a relief to you. Best wishes for a quick and easy recovery.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 12:30PM - edited Jan 28, 2011 03:37PM by grayeyes I'm not on the Team January 2011 list because I didn't know when a surgeon would agree to operate.  Fortunately, two good surgeons took me on Jan. 20.  Unilateral MX on left breast with TE.  (I already hate the TE.  Wish I'd gone smooth and natural.)  I stayed overnight only one night and checked out of the hospital the next night.  Refused the morphine at the hospital and took tylenol for two days.  Still one drain needs to be removed.  Doing OK, except I'd like this rock (the TE) out of my chest.  ;-) Good luck to everyone whose surgery is coming up.  You'll do fine.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC
